comments:
Steps to repro: 

1- Create a new project
2- Create a new Java file that contains annotations (like from a template, or
refreshing the project after a was file copied into the project)
3- Immediately delete the project after creating the file (before the APT
processing is complete).

The result is a JavaModelException:

Java Model Exception: Java Model Status [Project3 does not exist]

            at
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.core.JavaElement.newNotPresentException(JavaElement.java:468)

            at
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.core.JavaModelManager.getPerProjectInfoCheckExistence(JavaModelManager.java:1353)

            at
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.core.JavaProject.getPerProjectInfo(JavaProject.java:1785)

            at
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.core.JavaProject.getResolvedClasspath(JavaProject.java:1923)

            at

            at

            at

            at
org.eclipse.jdt.apt.core.internal.env.ProcessorEnvImpl.<init>(ProcessorEnvImpl.java:208)

            at
org.eclipse.jdt.apt.core.internal.env.ProcessorEnvImpl.newProcessorEnvironmentForReconcile(ProcessorEnvImpl.java:155)

            at

            at

            at

            at

            at

            at

            at

            at
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.core.ReconcileWorkingCopyOperation.executeOperation(ReconcileWorkingCopyOperation.java:59)

            at
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.core.JavaModelOperation.run(JavaModelOperation.java:718)

            at
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.core.JavaModelOperation.runOperation(JavaModelOperation.java:777)

            at
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.core.CompilationUnit.reconcile(CompilationUnit.java:1081)

            at

            at
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.text.CompositeReconcilingStrategy.reconcile(CompositeReconcilingStrategy.java:86)

John - is the exception reported anywhere but in STDERR/STDOUT? The message
should be harmless, and is just there to log possible failures. In this case,
it's expected that we should fail since the project has been deleted.

I think the exception is getting bubbled up to the default eclipse exception
handler.  The exception definitely appears in the Error Log view as a logged
exception (meaning that the stack trace is visible from the logged event's
properties and is logged with severity, ERROR).  

Off the top of my head, I think that an error dialog was popped, too. "An
internal error has occurred. See the log for more details" kind of a thing, but
I'll repro to be 100% sure that it really is showing up.

Just tried this out. I don't get a dialog, but I do get the error logged to the
Error Log. I think this is okay, as the user deleted the project mid-build, and
we'd rather not have the possibility of ignoring valuable errors that might look
like this one.

The stack trace to the console will be removed before we ship, tracked with bug
101322:

https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=101322
